docs.title: CodeGeass
docs.text: Claude Code Scheduler Framework - Orchestrate automated Claude Code sessions using CRON jobs with your Claude Pro/Max subscription.

docs.title: What is CodeGeass?
docs.text: CodeGeass lets you define reusable AI-powered tasks that run on schedules, execute skills, and track execution history. It's designed for developers who want to automate repetitive coding tasks using Claude's capabilities.

docs.title: Quick Install
docs.text:
# macOS
brew install pipx && pipx ensurepath && source ~/.zshrc

# Linux
python3 -m pip install --user pipx && pipx ensurepath && source ~/.bashrc

# Install CodeGeass + 24/7 scheduler
pipx install codegeass
codegeass setup

That's it! The scheduler is now running in the background.

docs.title: Create Your First Task
docs.text:
# Create a task that runs daily at 9 AM
codegeass task create \
  --name daily-review \
  --schedule "0 9 * * *" \
  --prompt "Review recent commits and summarize changes"

# Run it manually to test
codegeass task run daily-review

# Check upcoming scheduled runs
codegeass scheduler upcoming

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Scheduled Automation - Run Claude Code sessions on CRON schedules
  • Subscription-First - Uses your Claude Pro/Max subscription, not API credits
  • Multi-Project Support - Manage multiple projects from a single installation with shared skills
  • Skills System - Reusable, parameterized prompts following the Agent Skills standard
  • Plan Mode - Interactive approval workflow for complex tasks
  • Notifications - Get notified via Telegram, Discord, or Teams when tasks complete
  • Execution History - Full logging and session tracking
  • Web Dashboard - Visual management interface

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Solutions to common issues with CodeGeass.

docs.title: "codegeass: command not found"
docs.text:
Cause: CodeGeass not in PATH.

Solution: 

# Check installation
pip show codegeass

# Install if missing
pip install codegeass

# Or add to PATH
export PATH=$PATH:~/.local/bin

docs.title: Import Errors
docs.text:
Cause: Missing dependencies.

Solution: 

pip install codegeass[notifications]  # For Telegram/Discord
pip install codegeass[docs]           # For documentation

docs.title: Tasks Not Running on Schedule
docs.text:
Cause: CRON not installed or task disabled.

Solution: 

# Check CRON status
codegeass cron status

# If not installed
codegeass cron install

# Check task is enabled
codegeass task show my-task
# Look for: enabled: true

docs.title: "Task not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Task ID doesn't exist.

Solution: 

# List available tasks
codegeass task list

# Check spelling in schedules.yaml
cat config/schedules.yaml

docs.title: Task Fails Immediately
docs.text:
Cause: Invalid working directory or Claude CLI issues.

Solution: 

# Test the task
codegeass task run my-task

# Check logs
codegeass logs list --limit 1
codegeass logs show <execution-id>

# Verify working directory exists
ls -la /path/to/working/dir

# Verify Claude CLI works
claude --version

docs.title: CRON Job Not Firing
docs.text:
Cause: CRON service not running or misconfigured.

Solution: 

# Check CRON service
systemctl status cron

# Check crontab
crontab -l | grep codegeass

# Check CRON logs
grep codegeass /var/log/syslog
# or
journalctl -u cron | grep codegeass

docs.title: "codegeass: Permission denied" in CRON
docs.text:
Cause: File permissions or missing executable.

Solution: 

# Check Python path
which python

# Use absolute paths in crontab
* * * * * /usr/bin/python -m codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: PATH Issues in CRON
docs.text:
Cause: CRON has minimal PATH.

Solution: 

# Add PATH to crontab
PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/home/user/.local/bin
* * * * * codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: Telegram Not Sending
docs.text:
Cause: Invalid bot token or chat ID.

Solution: 

# Test notification
codegeass notification test telegram

# Verify credentials
cat ~/.codegeass/credentials.yaml

# Check bot token
curl "https://api.telegram.org/bot<TOKEN>/getMe"

# Get chat ID
curl "https://api.telegram.org/bot<TOKEN>/getUpdates"

docs.title: "Chat not found" Error
docs.text:
Cause: Bot not added to chat or wrong chat ID.

Solution: 1. Add bot to the group/channel 2. Send a message in the chat 3. Get updates to find the correct chat ID 4. Use negative ID for groups (e.g., -1001234567890)

docs.title: Discord Webhook Failing
docs.text:
Cause: Invalid or deleted webhook.

Solution: 

# Test webhook directly
curl -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"content": "Test"}' \
  "YOUR_WEBHOOK_URL"

# Verify in Discord: Channel Settings → Integrations → Webhooks

docs.title: Approval Not Appearing
docs.text:
Cause: Notifications not configured or plan creation failed.

Solution: 

# Check pending approvals
codegeass approval list

# Check notifications are configured
codegeass notification list

# Test notification
codegeass notification test telegram

docs.title: Approval Timeout
docs.text:
Cause: Approval window expired.

Solution: 

# Increase timeout in config/settings.yaml
plan_mode:
  default_timeout: 7200  # 2 hours instead of 1

docs.title: Plan Mode Task Stuck
docs.text:
Cause: Approval pending but not visible.

Solution: 

# List all approvals
codegeass approval list --all

# Check execution status
codegeass execution list

# Force reject if stuck
codegeass approval reject <id> --reason "Stuck, restarting"

docs.title: "No logs found"
docs.text:
Cause: No tasks have run or logs directory missing.

Solution: 

# Check logs directory
ls -la data/logs/

# Create if missing
mkdir -p data/logs data/sessions

# Run a task to generate logs
codegeass task run my-task

docs.title: Session Files Too Large
docs.text:
Cause: Verbose Claude output or many executions.

Solution: 

# Check disk usage
du -sh data/

# Clean old sessions
find data/sessions -name "*.json" -mtime +30 -delete
find data/logs -name "*.jsonl" -mtime +30 -delete

docs.title: "Claude CLI not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Claude Code not installed or not in PATH.

Solution: 

# Check Claude installation
claude --version

# If not installed, see:
# https://claude.ai/code

docs.title: Claude Authentication Issues
docs.text:
Cause: Not logged in or expired session.

Solution: 

# Re-authenticate
claude login

# Verify
claude --version

docs.title: "API key required" in CRON
docs.text:
Cause: CodeGeass unsets ANTHROPIC_API_KEY by design.

Explanation: This is intentional. CodeGeass uses your Claude Pro/Max subscription, not API credits. The Claude CLI should work without an API key if you're logged in.

Solution: 

# Ensure Claude CLI is authenticated
claude login

# Test Claude CLI works without API key
unset ANTHROPIC_API_KEY
claude -p "Hello"

docs.title: "Invalid YAML"
docs.text:
Cause: YAML syntax error.

Solution: 

# Validate YAML syntax
python -c "import yaml; yaml.safe_load(open('config/schedules.yaml'))"

# Common issues:
# - Missing quotes around special characters
# - Incorrect indentation
# - Tabs instead of spaces

docs.title: "Task ID already exists"
docs.text:
Cause: Duplicate task ID in schedules.yaml.

Solution: 

# Check for duplicates
grep -E "^  - id:" config/schedules.yaml | sort | uniq -d

# Use unique IDs for each task

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you can't resolve an issue:

  1. Check logs: 

    codegeass logs list --status failed
codegeass logs show <execution-id>

  2. Enable debug logging: 

    export CODEGEASS_LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG
codegeass task run my-task

  3. Report an issue: https://github.com/dontizi/codegeass/issues

Include: - CodeGeass version (codegeass --version) - Python version (python --version) - OS and version - Error messages - Steps to reproduce

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The CRON job runs codegeass scheduler run-due every minute:

* * * * * /path/to/python -m codegeass scheduler run-due

This: 1. Loads all tasks from config/schedules.yaml 2. Checks each task's schedule against the current time 3. Runs any tasks that are due 4. Logs results and sends notifications

docs.text:
┌───────────┐     ┌───────────┐     ┌────────────┐
│  Queued   │────>│  Running  │────>│ Completed  │
└───────────┘     └───────────┘     └────────────┘
                       │
                       │            ┌────────────┐
                       └───────────>│  Failed    │

Running ──> waiting_approval ──> approved ──> Completed

                 └──> timeout ──> Stopped

The scheduler is designed to run periodically via CRON:

│                    System CRON                          │
│  * * * * * /path/to/codegeass scheduler run-due         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
                           │
                           v
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                   run-due Command                       │
│                                                         │
│  1. Load tasks from config/schedules.yaml               │
│  2. Check which tasks are due (based on CRON schedule)  │
│  3. Execute each due task                               │
│  4. Log results                                         │
│  5. Send notifications                                  │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Execution Modes
docs.text: CodeGeass supports different execution strategies for running AI coding assistants. Each mode offers different capabilities and safety levels.

docs.title: Code Providers
docs.text: CodeGeass uses a Universal Provider Architecture that supports multiple AI coding assistants through a standardized adapter pattern.

docs.title: Supported Providers
docs.text: Provider Description Status Claude Code Anthropic's Claude CLI (claude) ✅ Default OpenAI Codex OpenAI's code assistant (codex) ✅ Available

docs.title: Provider Capabilities
docs.text:
Each provider declares its capabilities, which affects available execution modes:

codegeass provider info claude

Output shows: - Supported modes (headless, autonomous, skill) - Available models - Configuration requirements

docs.title: Headless Strategy (Default)
docs.text:
The safest mode - read-only execution using claude -p:

codegeass task create --mode headless ...

Capabilities: - Read files - Search code - Analyze codebases - Generate reports

Limitations: - Cannot modify files - Cannot run shell commands - Cannot create new files

Best for: - Code review - Analysis tasks - Report generation - Learning about codebases

docs.title: Autonomous Strategy
docs.text:
Full Claude capabilities with --dangerously-skip-permissions:

codegeass task create --mode autonomous ...

Capabilities: - All headless capabilities - Create, edit, delete files - Run shell commands - Install dependencies - Commit changes

Risks: - Unintended file modifications - Potential for destructive commands - Security considerations

Best for: - Automated refactoring - Code generation - Maintenance tasks - Trusted environments

Security Warning

Autonomous mode bypasses all safety checks. Only use on trusted projects where you accept the risk of unintended changes.

docs.title: Skill Strategy
docs.text:
Invokes predefined skills with controlled permissions:

codegeass task create --mode skill --skill review ...

Capabilities: - Defined by the skill's allowed-tools field - Scoped to specific operations - Predictable behavior

Best for: - Repeatable tasks - Controlled automation - Team standardization

docs.text:
1. Start with headless - Default for new tasks
  2. Use skill mode - When you have repeatable patterns
  3. Use autonomous sparingly - Only when file changes are required

docs.title: Safety Measures
docs.text:

  2. Review outputs - Check logs after each execution
  3. Use version control - Ensure changes can be reverted

docs.title: Plan Mode
docs.text: Plan mode adds an interactive approval workflow to task execution. Claude creates a plan, you review and approve, then execution continues.

docs.title: What is Plan Mode?
docs.text:
Plan mode splits execution into two phases:

  1. Planning Phase - Claude analyzes the task and creates a plan
  2. Execution Phase - After approval, Claude executes the plan
┌─────────────┐     ┌──────────────┐     ┌─────────────┐     ┌───────────┐
│   Task      │────>│   Claude     │────>│   Review    │────>│  Execute  │
│   Start     │     │   Plans      │     │   Approve   │     │   Plan    │
└─────────────┘     └──────────────┘     └──────────────┘     └───────────┘
                                                │
                                                v
                                         ┌───────────┐
                                         │   Reject  │
                                         │   (Stop)  │
                                         └───────────┘

docs.title: Why Use Plan Mode?
docs.text:
• Safety - Review changes before they happen
  • Control - Approve or reject proposed actions
  • Visibility - Understand what Claude will do
  • Collaboration - Human-in-the-loop automation

docs.title: Per Task
docs.text:
codegeass task create \
  --name careful-refactor \
  --mode autonomous \
  --plan-mode \
  --prompt "Refactor the authentication module"

docs.title: In YAML
docs.text:
tasks:
  - id: careful-refactor
    name: Careful Refactor
    schedule: "0 9 * * *"
    prompt: "Refactor the authentication module"
    mode: autonomous
    plan_mode: true

docs.title: 1. Task Runs and Creates Plan
docs.text:
When a plan-mode task executes, it pauses after planning:

$ codegeass task run careful-refactor
Task 'careful-refactor' started in plan mode
Waiting for approval...
Use 'codegeass approval list' to see pending approvals

docs.title: 2. Review Pending Approvals
docs.text:
$ codegeass approval list
ID        Task              Status    Created
────────────────────────────────────────────────
abc123    careful-refactor  pending   2024-01-15 09:00

docs.title: 3. View Plan Details
docs.text:
$ codegeass approval show abc123
Task: careful-refactor
Status: pending
Plan:
  1. Read current auth module (src/auth.py)
  2. Create new auth module with improved structure
  3. Update imports in dependent files
  4. Run tests to verify changes

docs.title: 4. Approve or Reject
docs.text:
# Approve the plan
codegeass approval approve abc123

# Reject the plan
codegeass approval reject abc123 --reason "Too risky"

docs.title: 5. Execution Continues
docs.text:
After approval, the task continues with the planned changes:

$ codegeass approval approve abc123
Plan approved. Execution continuing...
Task 'careful-refactor' completed successfully.

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text:
Plan mode integrates with notifications. When approval is needed, you receive an alert:

# config/notifications.yaml
channels:
  - id: telegram-approvals
    provider: telegram
    events:
      - approval_required
      - task_completed

See Notifications Setup for configuration.

docs.title: Timeout Handling
docs.text:
Plans expire after a configurable timeout (default: 1 hour):

# config/settings.yaml
plan_mode:
  default_timeout: 3600  # seconds

Expired plans are automatically rejected.

docs.title: When to Use Plan Mode
docs.text:
• Autonomous tasks - Any task that modifies files
  • Critical systems - Production codebases
  • Large changes - Refactoring, migrations
  • Team workflows - When multiple people need visibility

docs.title: When to Skip Plan Mode
docs.text:
• Headless tasks - Read-only tasks don't need approval
  • Well-tested skills - Trusted, repeatable operations
  • CI/CD pipelines - Where human approval isn't practical

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
1. Enable notifications - Don't miss approval requests
  2. Review carefully - Read the full plan before approving
  3. Use meaningful prompts - Clear instructions lead to better plans
  4. Set appropriate timeouts - Balance urgency with review time

docs.title: Example Workflow
docs.text:
Complete example of a plan mode task:

# Create the task
codegeass task create \
  --name upgrade-deps \
  --schedule "0 9 * * 1" \
  --mode autonomous \
  --plan-mode \
  --prompt "Check for outdated dependencies and upgrade them safely"

# Task runs Monday at 9 AM, creates plan, and waits

# You receive a Telegram notification: "Approval needed for 'upgrade-deps'"

# Review the plan
codegeass approval show <approval-id>

# If it looks good, approve
codegeass approval approve <approval-id>

# Task continues and completes
# You receive: "Task 'upgrade-deps' completed successfully"

docs.title: Projects
docs.text: CodeGeass supports managing multiple projects from a single installation through a global project registry.

docs.title: Why Multi-Project Support?
docs.text:
If you work on multiple codebases, you can:

  • Register each project once and switch between them easily
  • Share skills across all projects
  • Use project-specific configurations
  • Run tasks against any registered project

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
~/.codegeass/
├── projects.yaml         # Global project registry
└── skills/               # Shared skills (available to all projects)

/path/to/project-a/
├── config/
│   └── schedules.yaml    # Project A's tasks
└── .claude/skills/       # Project A's skills

/path/to/project-b/
├── config/
│   └── schedules.yaml    # Project B's tasks
└── .claude/skills/       # Project B's skills

docs.title: Project Registry
docs.text:
The global registry at ~/.codegeass/projects.yaml tracks all registered projects:

version: 1
default_project: abc12345
shared_skills_dir: ~/.codegeass/skills
projects:
  - id: abc12345
    name: my-app
    path: /home/user/projects/my-app
    description: "Main application"
    default_model: sonnet
    default_timeout: 300
    enabled: true
    use_shared_skills: true

docs.title: Register a Project
docs.text:
# Add a project from its directory
codegeass project add /path/to/project

# Add with options
codegeass project add /path/to/project \
  --name my-project \
  --description "My awesome project" \
  --model sonnet \
  --set-default

docs.title: List Projects
docs.text:
# List enabled projects
codegeass project list

# Include disabled projects
codegeass project list --all

docs.title: Show Project Details
docs.text: codegeass project show my-project

docs.title: Set Default Project
docs.text: codegeass project set-default my-project

docs.title: Initialize a New Project
docs.text:
# Initialize in current directory
codegeass project init

# Initialize in specific path
codegeass project init /path/to/new-project

docs.title: Remove a Project
docs.text:
# Unregister (doesn't delete files)
codegeass project remove my-project

docs.title: Update Project Settings
docs.text:
codegeass project update my-project \
  --model opus \
  --timeout 600 \
  --shared-skills

docs.title: Enable/Disable Projects
docs.text:
codegeass project enable my-project
codegeass project disable my-project

docs.title: Project Auto-Detection
docs.text:
When you run CodeGeass commands without specifying a project:

  1. Current Directory Check: If your current directory is within a registered project, that project is used
  2. Default Project: Falls back to the default project if set
  3. Single-Project Mode: If no projects are registered, uses the current directory

You can always override with the --project flag (must come before the command):

codegeass --project my-other-project task list

docs.title: Shared Skills
docs.text:
Skills placed in ~/.codegeass/skills/ are available to all projects:

~/.codegeass/skills/
├── review/
│   └── SKILL.md
├── security-scan/
│   └── SKILL.md
└── deploy/
    └── SKILL.md

docs.title: Skill Priority
docs.text:
When a skill is requested, CodeGeass looks in this order:

  1. Project skills (.claude/skills/) - highest priority
  2. Shared skills (~/.codegeass/skills/) - used if not found in project

This allows projects to override shared skills with custom versions.

docs.title: Disabling Shared Skills
docs.text:
If a project shouldn't use shared skills:

# When adding
codegeass project add /path/to/project --no-shared-skills

# Or update later
codegeass project update my-project --no-shared-skills

docs.title: Project Configuration
docs.text:
Each project can have its own defaults:

Setting Description Default default_model Claude model to use sonnet default_timeout Execution timeout (seconds) 300 default_autonomous Enable autonomous mode false use_shared_skills Include shared skills true

These defaults are used when creating new tasks in the project.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use descriptive names - Makes it easy to identify projects in lists
  2. Set a default project - Saves typing for your most-used project
  3. Leverage shared skills - Put common skills in ~/.codegeass/skills/
  4. Project-specific overrides - Override shared skills when needed
  5. Keep projects organized - Remove projects you no longer use

docs.title: Scheduling
docs.text: CodeGeass uses CRON expressions to schedule tasks. This guide explains CRON syntax and scheduling options.

docs.title: Common Patterns
docs.text: Expression Description 0 9 * * * Every day at 9:00 AM 0 9 * * 1-5 Weekdays at 9:00 AM */15 * * * * Every 15 minutes 0 */2 * * * Every 2 hours 0 9 1 * * First day of each month at 9:00 AM 0 9 * * 1 Every Monday at 9:00 AM 30 8 * * 1-5 Weekdays at 8:30 AM

docs.title: Special Characters
docs.text: Character Meaning Example * Any value * * * * * = every minute , List 0 9,17 * * * = 9 AM and 5 PM - Range 0 9 * * 1-5 = Mon-Fri / Step */15 * * * * = every 15 min

docs.title: Development Tasks
docs.text:
# Run tests every hour during work hours
codegeass task create \
  --name hourly-tests \
  --schedule "0 9-17 * * 1-5" \
  --prompt "Run the test suite and report failures"

# Daily code quality check at 6 AM
codegeass task create \
  --name quality-check \
  --schedule "0 6 * * *" \
  --prompt "Run linting and type checking, report issues"

docs.title: Reporting Tasks
docs.text:
# Weekly summary every Monday at 10 AM
codegeass task create \
  --name weekly-summary \
  --schedule "0 10 * * 1" \
  --prompt "Generate a weekly summary of project activity"

# Monthly report on the 1st at 9 AM
codegeass task create \
  --name monthly-report \
  --schedule "0 9 1 * *" \
  --prompt "Generate a monthly project status report"

docs.title: Maintenance Tasks
docs.text:
# Nightly dependency check at 2 AM
codegeass task create \
  --name dep-check \
  --schedule "0 2 * * *" \
  --prompt "Check for outdated dependencies and security issues"

# Sunday night cleanup at 11 PM
codegeass task create \
  --name cleanup \
  --schedule "0 23 * * 0" \
  --prompt "Clean up temporary files and old branches"

docs.title: Viewing Schedules
docs.text:
# See upcoming runs for all tasks
codegeass scheduler upcoming

# See next run for a specific task
codegeass task show my-task

docs.title: Installing the Scheduler
docs.text:
The scheduler runs as a CRON job that checks for due tasks:

# Install the CRON job
codegeass cron install

# Check status
codegeass scheduler status

# View the CRON entry
crontab -l | grep codegeass

docs.title: Time Zones
docs.text:
CRON uses system time. To check your system timezone:

timedatectl show --property=Timezone

UTC for Servers

For servers, consider using UTC to avoid daylight saving time issues.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Stagger schedules - Don't run all tasks at the same time
  2. Use work hours - Schedule interactive tasks during your active hours
  3. Consider timezones - Be aware of when tasks will actually run
  4. Test manually - Always test with codegeass task run before scheduling
  5. Monitor executions - Check codegeass logs list regularly

docs.title: Task Not Running
docs.text:
# Check if scheduler is installed
codegeass scheduler status

# Check if task is enabled
codegeass task show my-task

# Check CRON logs
grep codegeass /var/log/syslog

docs.title: Wrong Time
docs.text:

date

# Check timezone
timedatectl

# Verify CRON expression
codegeass scheduler upcoming

docs.title: Skills
docs.text: Skills are reusable, parameterized prompts that follow the Agent Skills open standard.

docs.title: What is a Skill?
docs.text:
A skill is a markdown file with YAML frontmatter that defines:

  • Metadata (name, description)
  • Execution context
  • Tool permissions
  • The prompt template
---
name: code-review
description: Review code changes and provide feedback
context: fork
agent: Explore
allowed-tools: Read, Grep, Glob
---

# Review the following code

$ARGUMENTS

Focus on:
- Code quality
- Potential bugs
- Performance issues

docs.title: Skill Location
docs.text: Skills can be stored in two locations:

docs.title: Project Skills
docs.text:
Project-specific skills live in .claude/skills/:

project/
└── .claude/
    └── skills/
        ├── review/
        │   └── SKILL.md
        ├── test/
        │   └── SKILL.md
        └── deploy/
            └── SKILL.md

docs.title: Shared Skills
docs.text:
Global skills available to all projects live in ~/.codegeass/skills/:

~/.codegeass/
└── skills/
    ├── review/
    │   └── SKILL.md
    ├── security-scan/
    │   └── SKILL.md
    └── dependency-check/
        └── SKILL.md

Skill Priority

Project skills take priority over shared skills with the same name. This allows you to override shared skills with project-specific versions.

docs.title: Frontmatter Fields
docs.text: Field Required Description name Yes Skill identifier description Yes What the skill does context No Execution context (fork, current) agent No Agent type (Explore, general) allowed-tools No Comma-separated list of allowed tools

docs.title: Template Variables
docs.text:
• $ARGUMENTS - Replaced with user-provided arguments
  • Jinja2 templates supported for complex logic

docs.title: Basic Skill
docs.text:
# Create skill directory
mkdir -p .claude/skills/my-skill

# Create SKILL.md
cat > .claude/skills/my-skill/SKILL.md << 'EOF'
---
name: my-skill
description: Does something useful
---

# Instructions

$ARGUMENTS

Do the thing.
EOF

docs.title: Validate Skill
docs.text: codegeass skill validate .claude/skills/my-skill/SKILL.md

docs.title: List Available Skills
docs.text: codegeass skill list

docs.title: With Tasks
docs.text:
codegeass task create \
  --name skill-task \
  --schedule "0 9 * * *" \
  --mode skill \
  --skill review \
  --skill-args "Review the authentication module"

docs.title: Manual Invocation
docs.text: codegeass skill run review "Check the API endpoints"

docs.title: Code Review Skill
docs.text:
---
name: review
description: Review code changes for quality and issues
context: fork
agent: Explore
allowed-tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash
---

# Code Review

Review the following:

$ARGUMENTS

## Review Checklist

- [ ] Code follows project conventions
- [ ] No obvious bugs or logic errors
- [ ] Error handling is appropriate
- [ ] Performance is acceptable
- [ ] Security considerations addressed

Provide specific, actionable feedback.

docs.title: Test Runner Skill
docs.text:
---
name: test
description: Run tests and report results
context: current
allowed-tools: Bash, Read
---

# Run Tests

$ARGUMENTS

Execute the test suite and:
1. Report any failures with context
2. Suggest fixes for failing tests
3. Note any skipped or slow tests

docs.title: Documentation Skill
docs.text:
---
name: document
description: Generate or update documentation
context: fork
allowed-tools: Read, Grep, Write
---

# Documentation Task

$ARGUMENTS

Update documentation to:
- Reflect current code behavior
- Include examples
- Follow project documentation style

docs.title: fork Context
docs.text:
• Creates an isolated environment
  • Changes don't affect the main project
  • Best for exploratory or risky operations

docs.title: current Context
docs.text:
• Runs in the current working directory
  • Changes are applied directly
  • Use when you want immediate results

docs.title: Included Skills
docs.text: CodeGeass ships with several powerful skills that you can use immediately.

docs.title: review
docs.text:
Comprehensive code review for PRs or recent changes.

What it checks:

  • Correctness: Logic errors, edge cases, null handling
  • Security: Injection vulnerabilities, secrets exposure, auth issues
  • Performance: N+1 queries, unnecessary loops, memory leaks
  • Maintainability: Complexity, naming, documentation
  • Tests: Coverage, edge cases, meaningful assertions

Usage:

codegeass task create \
  --name daily-review \
  --skill review \
  --schedule "0 9 * * 1-5"

Output format: Returns a structured JSON report with issues categorized by severity (critical, important, suggestion) and type.

docs.title: security-scan
docs.text:
Deep security analysis of your codebase.

What it detects:

  • Secrets: API keys, tokens, passwords, private keys in code
  • Dependency vulnerabilities: CVEs in packages (pip-audit, npm audit)
  • Code vulnerabilities: SQL injection, XSS, command injection, path traversal
  • Configuration issues: Debug mode, permissive CORS, missing security headers

Usage:

codegeass task create \
  --name weekly-security \
  --skill security-scan \
  --schedule "0 2 * * 0"

Output format: Returns a JSON security report with findings, severity levels, CWE references, and remediation suggestions.

docs.title: refactor
docs.text:
Automated refactoring of monolithic code into clean, single-responsibility modules.

What it does:

  • Identifies files exceeding size/complexity thresholds
  • Analyzes responsibilities and suggests splits
  • Extracts modules following SOLID principles
  • Preserves backward compatibility via re-exports
  • Tests changes with linting and existing tests

Usage:

codegeass task create \
  --name weekly-refactor \
  --skill refactor \
  --skill-args "src/codegeass/cli/" \
  --schedule "0 3 * * 0"

Output: Creates a PR with modular code structure and detailed explanation of changes.

docs.text:
1. Be specific - Clear instructions get better results
  2. Use allowed-tools - Limit tools to what's needed

  4. Test first - Validate skills before using in scheduled tasks
  5. Version control - Keep skills in your repo
  6. Use shared skills - Put commonly-used skills in ~/.codegeass/skills/
  7. Override when needed - Project skills take priority over shared ones

docs.title: Tasks
docs.text: Tasks are the core unit of work in CodeGeass. Each task defines what Claude should do and when it should run.

docs.title: What is a Task?
docs.text:
A task combines:

  • A prompt or skill - Instructions for Claude
  • A schedule - When to run (CRON expression)
  • Configuration - Working directory, execution mode, etc.
id: daily-review
name: Daily Code Review
schedule: "0 9 * * 1-5"
prompt: "Review commits from the last 24 hours and summarize changes"
working_dir: /home/user/project
mode: headless
enabled: true

docs.title: Via CLI
docs.text:
# Basic task
codegeass task create \
  --name my-task \
  --schedule "0 9 * * *" \
  --prompt "Your instructions here"

# With all options
codegeass task create \
  --name my-task \
  --schedule "0 9 * * *" \
  --prompt "Your instructions" \
  --working-dir /path/to/project \
  --mode autonomous \
  --plan-mode

docs.title: Via YAML
docs.text:
Edit config/schedules.yaml directly:

tasks:
  - id: my-task
    name: My Task
    schedule: "0 9 * * *"
    prompt: "Your instructions here"
    working_dir: /path/to/project
    mode: headless
    enabled: true

docs.title: Headless Mode (Default)
docs.text:
Safe, read-only execution using claude -p:

codegeass task create --name safe-task --mode headless ...
  • Cannot modify files
  • Best for analysis, reporting, code review
  • No risk of unintended changes

docs.title: Autonomous Mode
docs.text:
Full Claude capabilities with --dangerously-skip-permissions:

codegeass task create --name auto-task --mode autonomous ...
  • Can create, edit, and delete files
  • Can run shell commands
  • Use only on trusted projects

Use with Caution

Autonomous mode gives Claude full control. Only use this on projects where you trust the outcome.

docs.title: Skill Mode
docs.text:
Invokes a predefined skill:

codegeass task create --name skill-task --mode skill --skill review ...
  • Uses skills from .claude/skills/
  • Follows the Agent Skills standard
  • Parameters passed via arguments

docs.title: Managing Tasks
docs.text:
# List all tasks
codegeass task list

# Show task details
codegeass task show <task-id>

# Enable/disable
codegeass task enable <task-id>
codegeass task disable <task-id>

# Run manually
codegeass task run <task-id>

# Delete
codegeass task delete <task-id>

docs.title: Task with Plan Mode
docs.text:
Plan mode adds an approval step before execution:

codegeass task create \
  --name careful-task \
  --mode autonomous \
  --plan-mode \
  --prompt "Refactor the authentication module"

When run: 1. Claude creates a plan 2. You receive a notification to approve 3. After approval, execution continues 4. Full results are logged

See Plan Mode for details.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Start with headless mode - Only use autonomous when needed
  2. Use specific prompts - Clear instructions get better results
  3. Test manually first - Run codegeass task run before enabling schedules
  4. Enable notifications - Know when tasks complete or fail
  5. Review logs regularly - Check codegeass logs list for issues

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: CodeGeass uses YAML files for configuration. This guide explains all configuration options.

docs.title: Configuration Files
docs.text:
./config/                     # Project configuration
├── schedules.yaml            # Task definitions
├── settings.yaml             # Project settings
└── notifications.yaml        # Notification channels

~/.codegeass/                 # Global user configuration
├── projects.yaml             # Project registry (multi-project mode)
├── credentials.yaml          # Secrets (API keys, tokens)
└── skills/                   # Shared skills (available to all projects)
    ├── review/
    │   └── SKILL.md
    └── security-scan/
        └── SKILL.md

docs.title: schedules.yaml
docs.text:
Defines all scheduled tasks:

tasks:
  - id: daily-review
    name: Daily Code Review
    schedule: "0 9 * * 1-5"
    prompt: "Review commits from the last 24 hours"
    working_dir: /home/user/project
    enabled: true
    mode: headless

  - id: weekly-report
    name: Weekly Summary
    schedule: "0 10 * * 1"
    prompt: "Generate a weekly summary of project activity"
    enabled: true
    mode: autonomous

docs.title: Task Fields
docs.text:
Field Type Required Description id string Yes Unique task identifier name string No Human-readable name schedule string Yes CRON expression prompt string Yes* Instructions for Claude skill string Yes* Skill to invoke (if using skill mode) working_dir string No Directory to run in enabled bool No Whether task is active (default: true) mode string No Execution mode (default: headless) plan_mode bool No Enable plan mode for approval workflow

*Either prompt or skill is required, not both.

docs.title: settings.yaml
docs.text:
Project-wide settings:

# Default working directory for tasks
default_working_dir: /home/user/project

# Default execution mode
default_mode: headless

# Logging settings
logging:
  level: INFO
  format: json

# Session settings
sessions:
  retention_days: 30
  max_sessions: 1000

# Plan mode settings
plan_mode:
  default_timeout: 3600  # seconds
  auto_approve: false

docs.title: notifications.yaml
docs.text:
Notification channel configuration:

channels:
  - id: telegram-main
    provider: telegram
    enabled: true
    events:
      - task_completed
      - task_failed
      - approval_required

  - id: discord-alerts
    provider: discord
    enabled: true
    events:
      - task_failed

Secrets Storage

API keys and tokens are stored in ~/.codegeass/credentials.yaml, not in the project config.

docs.title: credentials.yaml
docs.text:
Global secrets file (never commit this):

# Telegram Bot
telegram:
  bot_token: "123456:ABC-DEF..."
  chat_id: "-1001234567890"

# Discord Webhook
discord:
  webhook_url: "https://discord.com/api/webhooks/..."

Set restrictive permissions:

chmod 600 ~/.codegeass/credentials.yaml

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Settings can be overridden with environment variables:

Variable Description CODEGEASS_CONFIG_DIR Override config directory CODEGEASS_DATA_DIR Override data directory CODEGEASS_LOG_LEVEL Set log level (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR)

docs.title: Validation
docs.text:
Validate your configuration:

# Validate task configuration
codegeass task list

# Validate skill files
codegeass skill validate .claude/skills/my-skill/SKILL.md

# Check notification setup
codegeass notification list

docs.title: projects.yaml
docs.text:
Global project registry for multi-project mode:

version: 1
default_project: abc12345
shared_skills_dir: ~/.codegeass/skills
projects:
  - id: abc12345
    name: my-project
    path: /home/user/projects/my-project
    description: "Main application"
    default_model: sonnet
    default_timeout: 300
    default_autonomous: false
    git_remote: https://github.com/user/repo
    enabled: true
    use_shared_skills: true
    created_at: "2024-01-15T09:00:00Z"

Automatic Registration

This file is managed by codegeass project add/remove commands. You typically don't edit it directly.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide covers installing CodeGeass and its dependencies.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.10+ - CodeGeass requires Python 3.10 or later
  • Claude Code - The Claude CLI tool must be installed and authenticated
  • Git - Required for version control features

docs.title: Install Claude Code
docs.text:
First, ensure Claude Code is installed:

# Check if Claude Code is installed
claude --version

# If not installed, follow instructions at:
# https://claude.ai/code

docs.title: Using pipx (Recommended)
docs.text:
pipx installs Python CLI tools in isolated environments. This is the recommended method because it:

  • Keeps CodeGeass isolated from your system Python
  • Avoids dependency conflicts
  • Makes the codegeass command globally available
# Install pipx first

# macOS
brew install pipx
pipx ensurepath

# Linux (Debian/Ubuntu)
sudo apt install pipx
pipx ensurepath

# Linux (other) or if apt doesn't have pipx
python3 -m pip install --user pipx
pipx ensurepath

# Restart your terminal, then install CodeGeass
pipx install codegeass

docs.title: Using pip (in a virtual environment)
docs.text:
If you prefer pip, we strongly recommend using a virtual environment:

# Create a dedicated virtual environment
python3 -m venv ~/.codegeass-venv

# Activate it
source ~/.codegeass-venv/bin/activate

# Install CodeGeass
pip install codegeass

# Add to your PATH permanently (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc)
echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.codegeass-venv/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc

Avoid pip install without a virtual environment

On modern systems (macOS, Ubuntu 23+), installing packages system-wide with pip is restricted. Always use pipx or a virtual environment.

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
For development or to get the latest changes:

git clone https://github.com/dontizi/codegeass.git
cd codegeass
pip install -e .

docs.title: With Optional Dependencies
docs.text:
# With notification support (Telegram, Discord, Teams)
pipx install "codegeass[notifications]"

# If using pip in a venv:
pip install "codegeass[notifications]"

# With development tools
pip install "codegeass[dev]"

# With documentation tools
pip install "codegeass[docs]"

# Everything
pip install "codegeass[notifications,dev,docs]"

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
# Check version
codegeass --version

# View available commands
codegeass --help

Expected output:

Usage: codegeass [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

  CodeGeass - Claude Code Scheduler Framework

Options:
  --version  Show the version and exit.
  --help     Show this message and exit.

Commands:
  approval      Manage plan mode approvals
  dashboard     Start the web dashboard
  execution     Manage task executions
  init          Initialize project structure
  logs          View execution logs
  notification  Manage notifications
  project       Manage projects
  provider      Manage code providers
  scheduler     Scheduler operations
  setup         Install 24/7 scheduler
  skill         Manage skills
  task          Manage scheduled tasks
  uninstall-scheduler  Remove the scheduler

docs.title: Setup the 24/7 Scheduler
docs.text:
After installing CodeGeass, run the setup command to install the background scheduler:

codegeass setup

This will:

  1. Detect your operating system
  2. Install the appropriate scheduler:
  3. macOS: launchd service (~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist)
  4. Linux: systemd user timer (~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass-scheduler.timer)
  5. Start the scheduler immediately

The scheduler runs every minute and executes any due tasks automatically.

docs.text:

docs.text:
If the scheduler is already installed, setup will detect it and skip reinstallation:

CodeGeass Setup

Detected OS: Darwin
CodeGeass path: /Users/you/.local/bin/codegeass

✓ Scheduler already installed (launchd (running))
Use --force to reinstall

docs.title: Force reinstall
docs.text:
Use --force to reinstall the scheduler (useful after upgrading CodeGeass):

codegeass setup --force

Reinstalling scheduler (was: launchd (running))...
Using launchd (macOS native)
✓ Scheduler reinstalled (launchd)

docs.title: Verify Scheduler is Running
docs.text:
# macOS
launchctl list | grep codegeass

# Linux
systemctl --user status codegeass-scheduler.timer

docs.title: View Scheduler Logs
docs.text:
# macOS
cat /tmp/codegeass-scheduler.log
cat /tmp/codegeass-scheduler.err

journalctl --user -u codegeass-scheduler -f

docs.text:
pipx upgrade codegeass

source ~/.codegeass-venv/bin/activate
pip install --upgrade codegeass

# Reinstall the scheduler to use the new version
codegeass setup --force

docs.title: To a specific version
docs.text:
pipx install codegeass==0.3.0 --force

# or with pip
pip install codegeass==0.3.0

docs.title: Quick Uninstall (Everything)
docs.text:
Remove CodeGeass completely with one command:

codegeass uninstall --all

Output: 

CodeGeass Uninstall

This will remove:
  - Scheduler service (launchd (running))
  - Global config (/Users/you/.codegeass)
  - Project config (/path/to/project/config)
  - Project data (/path/to/project/data)

Are you sure you want to continue? [y/N]: y

✓ Global config removed (/Users/you/.codegeass)
✓ Project config removed (/path/to/project/config)
✓ Project data removed (/path/to/project/data)

│                                          │
│ To remove the Python package:            │

╰──────────────────────────────────────────╯

Then remove the package:

pipx uninstall codegeass

docs.title: Uninstall Options
docs.text: Command What it removes codegeass uninstall Scheduler only codegeass uninstall --all Everything (scheduler + config + data) codegeass uninstall --all --keep-global Everything except ~/.codegeass/ codegeass uninstall --all --keep-project Everything except config/ and data/ codegeass uninstall --all -y Everything, skip confirmation

docs.title: What Gets Removed
docs.text:
Flag Scheduler Global Config Project Config Project Data (none) ✓ - - - --all ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ --all --keep-global ✓ - ✓ ✓ --all --keep-project ✓ ✓ - -

Locations:

  • Scheduler: ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist (macOS) or ~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass-scheduler.* (Linux)
  • Global config: ~/.codegeass/ (credentials, shared skills, project registry)
  • Project config: ./config/ (tasks, settings, notifications)
  • Project data: ./data/ (logs, sessions)

docs.title: Remove scheduler only
docs.text:
codegeass uninstall-scheduler

This keeps all your tasks, logs, and configuration intact.

docs.title: Remove package only (keep data)
docs.text:
# First remove scheduler
codegeass uninstall-scheduler

# Then uninstall package
pipx uninstall codegeass

Your config and data remain for future reinstallation.

docs.title: Manual Cleanup
docs.text:
If you already uninstalled the package and need to clean up:

Remove scheduler manually:

# macOS
launchctl unload ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist
rm ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist

# Linux
systemctl --user disable --now codegeass-scheduler.timer
rm ~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass-scheduler.timer
rm ~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass-scheduler.service
systemctl --user daemon-reload

Remove data manually:

# Global config
rm -rf ~/.codegeass

# Project config (in each project directory)
rm -rf config/ data/

docs.title: Permission denied on macOS
docs.text:
If you get a permission error when installing with pipx:

mkdir -p ~/.local/bin
chmod 755 ~/.local/bin
pipx install codegeass

docs.title: Command not found after install
docs.text:
Restart your terminal or run:

source ~/.bashrc  # or ~/.zshrc on macOS

docs.title: externally-managed-environment error
docs.text:
This error means your system Python is protected. Use pipx instead:

# macOS
brew install pipx && pipx ensurepath

# Then restart terminal and install
pipx install codegeass

docs.title: Scheduler won't start
docs.text:
Check the logs:

# macOS
cat /tmp/codegeass-scheduler.log
cat /tmp/codegeass-scheduler.err

# Linux
journalctl --user -u codegeass-scheduler -f

Common issues:

  • codegeass not found: The scheduler can't find the codegeass command. Reinstall with codegeass setup --force
  • Permission denied: Check file permissions in your project directory
  • No tasks: The scheduler runs but there are no due tasks. Check codegeass scheduler upcoming

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
After installation, CodeGeass uses these directories:

~/.codegeass/              # Global user config
├── projects.yaml          # Project registry
├── credentials.yaml       # API keys, secrets (gitignored)
└── skills/                # Shared skills (available to all projects)

./config/                  # Project config (in your repo)
├── schedules.yaml         # Task definitions
├── settings.yaml          # Project settings
└── notifications.yaml     # Notification channels

./data/                    # Runtime data (gitignored)
├── logs/                  # Execution logs (JSONL)
└── sessions/              # Claude session data

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with CodeGeass in 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 1: Install CodeGeass
docs.text:
# macOS
brew install pipx && pipx ensurepath
source ~/.zshrc

# Linux
python3 -m pip install --user pipx && pipx ensurepath
source ~/.bashrc

# Install CodeGeass
pipx install codegeass

docs.title: Step 2: Setup the Scheduler
docs.text:
Run the setup command to install the 24/7 background scheduler:

codegeass setup

This automatically detects your OS and installs: - macOS: launchd service - Linux: systemd user timer

The scheduler runs every minute and executes any due tasks.

docs.title: Step 3: Create Your First Task
docs.text:
Create a simple task that runs daily:

codegeass task create \
  --name hello-world \
  --schedule "0 9 * * *" \
  --prompt "Say hello and tell me today's date"

This creates a task named hello-world that runs at 9 AM every day.

docs.title: Step 4: View Your Task

codegeass task list

# Show task details
codegeass task show hello-world

docs.title: Step 5: Run Manually

codegeass task run hello-world

Working Directory

By default, tasks run in the current directory. Use --working-dir to specify a different location.

docs.title: Step 6: Check Results
docs.text:

# List recent executions
codegeass logs list

# Show detailed log

# Follow logs in real-time
codegeass logs tail

docs.title: Step 7: Verify Scheduling

# Check upcoming runs
codegeass scheduler upcoming

# View scheduler status
codegeass scheduler status

# Check scheduler is running
# macOS
launchctl list | grep codegeass

# Linux
systemctl --user status codegeass-scheduler.timer

docs.title: A Real-World Example
docs.text:
Here's a more practical task - daily code review:

codegeass task create \
  --name daily-review \
  --schedule "0 9 * * 1-5" \
  --prompt "Review commits from the last 24 hours. Summarize changes and flag any potential issues." \
  --working-dir /path/to/your/project \
  --mode autonomous

Autonomous Mode

The --mode autonomous flag allows Claude to make file changes. Use with caution and only on trusted projects.

docs.title: Working with Multiple Projects
docs.text:
If you work on multiple codebases, you can register them with CodeGeass:

# Register your projects
codegeass project add ~/projects/api-server --name api
codegeass project add ~/projects/web-app --name web
codegeass project add ~/projects/mobile-app --name mobile

# Set a default
codegeass project set-default api

# List registered projects
codegeass project list

# Run tasks against specific projects
codegeass --project web task run daily-review

Shared Skills

Place commonly-used skills in ~/.codegeass/skills/ to make them available across all your projects.

codegeass dashboard

docs.title: Creating Tasks
docs.text: This guide walks through creating effective scheduled tasks in CodeGeass.

docs.title: Basic Task Creation
docs.text:
The simplest task requires a name, schedule, and prompt:

codegeass task create \
  --name my-task \
  --schedule "0 9 * * *" \
  --prompt "Your instructions here"

docs.title: 1. Choose a Meaningful Name
docs.text:
Task names should be: - Descriptive and lowercase - Use hyphens for spaces - Unique within your project

# Good names
daily-code-review
weekly-report
dependency-check

# Avoid
task1
my-task
thing

docs.title: 2. Define the Schedule
docs.text:
Use CRON expressions to specify when tasks run:

# Every day at 9 AM
--schedule "0 9 * * *"

# Weekdays at 9 AM
--schedule "0 9 * * 1-5"

# Every 6 hours
--schedule "0 */6 * * *"

# Monday at 10 AM
--schedule "0 10 * * 1"

Test Your Schedule

Use crontab.guru to verify CRON expressions.

docs.title: 3. Write Clear Prompts
docs.text:
Good prompts are: - Specific - Say exactly what you want - Scoped - Focus on one thing - Actionable - Request concrete outputs

# Good prompt
--prompt "Review commits from the last 24 hours. List any potential bugs, security issues, or code style violations. Summarize findings in a bullet list."

# Too vague
--prompt "Look at the code"

docs.title: 4. Choose Execution Mode
docs.text:
Mode Use When headless Reading, analyzing, reporting (default) autonomous Making file changes skill Using a predefined skill 
# Read-only analysis
--mode headless

# Allowing file changes
--mode autonomous

# Using a skill
--mode skill --skill review

docs.title: 5. Set Working Directory
docs.text:
Specify where the task should run:

--working-dir /path/to/your/project

If not specified, uses the current directory.

docs.title: Daily Code Review
docs.text:
codegeass task create \
  --name daily-review \
  --schedule "0 9 * * 1-5" \
  --prompt "Review commits from the last 24 hours. Check for:
- Potential bugs
- Security issues
- Code style violations
- Missing tests
Provide a summary with specific file references." \
  --working-dir /home/user/myproject \
  --mode headless

docs.title: Weekly Dependency Check
docs.text:
codegeass task create \
  --name weekly-deps \
  --schedule "0 10 * * 1" \
  --prompt "Check for outdated dependencies. List:
- Outdated packages with current and latest versions
- Security vulnerabilities
- Recommended updates
Do not make changes, just report findings." \
  --working-dir /home/user/myproject \
  --mode headless

docs.title: Automated Test Runner
docs.text:
codegeass task create \
  --name test-runner \
  --schedule "0 */4 * * *" \
  --prompt "Run the test suite. If any tests fail:
1. Identify the failing tests
2. Analyze the error messages
3. Suggest potential fixes
Report results concisely." \
  --working-dir /home/user/myproject \
  --mode headless

docs.title: Code Cleanup with Approval
docs.text:
codegeass task create \
  --name code-cleanup \
  --schedule "0 6 * * 6" \
  --prompt "Clean up the codebase:
- Remove unused imports
- Fix formatting issues
- Add missing type hints
Create small, focused changes." \
  --working-dir /home/user/myproject \
  --mode autonomous \
  --plan-mode

docs.title: Testing Your Task
docs.text:
Always test manually before enabling schedules:

# Run the task immediately
codegeass task run daily-review

# Check the output
codegeass logs list --limit 1
codegeass logs show <execution-id>

docs.title: Modifying Tasks
docs.text: Tasks are stored in config/schedules.yaml. You can:

docs.title: Edit via CLI
docs.text:
# Disable temporarily
codegeass task disable daily-review

# Re-enable
codegeass task enable daily-review

# Delete
codegeass task delete old-task

docs.title: Edit YAML Directly
docs.text:
# config/schedules.yaml
tasks:
  - id: daily-review
    name: Daily Review

docs.title: CRON Automation Setup
docs.text: This guide explains how to set up CRON for automatic task execution.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
CodeGeass uses system CRON to check for due tasks every minute:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    System CRON                          │
│  * * * * * codegeass scheduler run-due                  │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
                           │
                           │ Every minute
                           v
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                   CodeGeass Scheduler                   │
│  - Loads tasks from config/schedules.yaml               │
│  - Checks which tasks are due now                       │
│  - Executes due tasks                                   │
│  - Logs results                                         │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Quick Setup
docs.text:
# Install the CRON job
codegeass cron install

# Verify installation
codegeass cron status

That's it! Tasks will now run automatically according to their schedules.

docs.title: Manual Setup
docs.text: If automatic installation doesn't work, set up CRON manually:

docs.title: Step 1: Find Python Path
docs.text:
which python
# or
which python3

docs.title: Step 2: Find CodeGeass Path
docs.text: which codegeass

docs.title: Step 3: Edit Crontab
docs.text:
crontab -e

Add this line (adjust paths):

* * * * * /path/to/python -m codegeass scheduler run-due >> /tmp/codegeass-cron.log 2>&1

docs.title: Step 4: Verify
docs.text:
# Check crontab
crontab -l | grep codegeass

# Watch the log
tail -f /tmp/codegeass-cron.log

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: CRON runs with minimal environment. Important considerations:

docs.title: Claude Pro/Max Usage
docs.text:
CodeGeass deliberately unsets ANTHROPIC_API_KEY in CRON to use your subscription:

# This happens automatically in CRON context
os.environ.pop('ANTHROPIC_API_KEY', None)

docs.title: Custom Environment
docs.text:
If you need specific environment variables, add them to crontab:

SHELL=/bin/bash
PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin
CODEGEASS_LOG_LEVEL=INFO

* * * * * /path/to/python -m codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: CRON Output
docs.text:
Redirect CRON output to a log file:

* * * * * /path/to/codegeass scheduler run-due >> /var/log/codegeass-cron.log 2>&1

docs.title: Task Logs
docs.text:
Task execution logs are always stored in data/logs/:

# View recent executions
codegeass logs list

# Tail logs
codegeass logs tail

docs.title: Check CRON is Running
docs.text:
# View status
codegeass cron status

# Check system CRON logs
grep codegeass /var/log/syslog
# or
journalctl -u cron | grep codegeass

docs.title: Check Tasks are Being Picked Up
docs.text:
# View upcoming runs
codegeass scheduler upcoming

# Manually trigger run-due
codegeass scheduler run-due --dry-run

docs.title: Test a Specific Task
docs.text:
# Run task manually
codegeass task run my-task

# Check it completed
codegeass logs list --limit 1

docs.title: Tasks Not Running
docs.text:
Check CRON is installed: 

codegeass cron status
crontab -l | grep codegeass

Check task is enabled: 

codegeass task show my-task
# Look for: enabled: true

Check schedule: 

codegeass scheduler upcoming

Run manually: 

codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: Permission Issues
docs.text:
Ensure directories are writable: 

ls -la data/
ls -la data/logs/
ls -la data/sessions/

Create if missing: 

mkdir -p data/logs data/sessions

docs.title: Path Issues
docs.text:
CRON can't find codegeass: 

# Use absolute path in crontab
which codegeass
# Result: /home/user/.local/bin/codegeass

# Update crontab with full path
* * * * * /home/user/.local/bin/codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: Claude CLI Issues
docs.text:
Claude not found: 

# Check Claude is installed
claude --version

# Add to PATH in crontab
PATH=/usr/local/bin:/home/user/.local/bin:$PATH
* * * * * codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: Run Every 5 Minutes
docs.text:
If you don't need minute-level precision:

*/5 * * * * codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: Multiple Projects
docs.text:
For multiple projects with different configs:

* * * * * cd /home/user/project1 && codegeass scheduler run-due
* * * * * cd /home/user/project2 && codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: Systemd Alternative
docs.text:
For systemd-based systems, you can use a timer instead of CRON:

# ~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass.service
[Unit]
Description=CodeGeass Scheduler

[Service]
Type=oneshot
WorkingDirectory=/home/user/myproject
ExecStart=/usr/bin/python -m codegeass scheduler run-due

# ~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass.timer
[Unit]
Description=Run CodeGeass every minute

[Timer]
OnCalendar=*:*:00
Persistent=true

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target

systemctl --user enable --now codegeass.timer

docs.title: Uninstall CRON Job
docs.text: codegeass cron uninstall

docs.title: Disable Temporarily
docs.text:
# Comment out in crontab
crontab -e
# Add # at beginning of line

# Or disable all tasks
codegeass task list | while read id; do codegeass task disable $id; done

docs.title: Clean Old Logs
docs.text:
# View log stats
codegeass logs stats

# Manual cleanup (keep last 30 days)
find data/logs -name "*.jsonl" -mtime +30 -delete
find data/sessions -name "*.json" -mtime +30 -delete

docs.title: Plan Mode Workflow
docs.text: This guide explains how to use plan mode for safe, controlled automation with human approval.

docs.title: Why Plan Mode?
docs.text:
Plan mode adds a review step before Claude makes changes:

  1. Claude analyzes the task and creates a plan
  2. You review the plan and approve or reject
  3. Only after approval does execution continue

This is essential for: - Autonomous tasks that modify files - Critical codebases where mistakes are costly - Team environments where visibility is important

docs.title: On a New Task
docs.text:
codegeass task create \
  --name refactor-auth \
  --schedule "0 9 * * 1" \
  --prompt "Refactor the authentication module for better security" \
  --mode autonomous \
  --plan-mode

docs.title: On an Existing Task
docs.text:
Edit config/schedules.yaml:

tasks:
  - id: refactor-auth
    schedule: "0 9 * * 1"
    prompt: "Refactor the authentication module"
    mode: autonomous
    plan_mode: true  # Add this line

docs.title: Step 1: Task Runs and Creates Plan
docs.text:
When the scheduled time arrives (or you run manually):

$ codegeass task run refactor-auth
Task 'refactor-auth' started in plan mode
Creating plan...
Plan created. Waiting for approval.
Approval ID: abc123

docs.title: Step 2: You Receive a Notification
docs.text:
If notifications are configured, you'll get an alert:

🔔 Approval Required: refactor-auth

Plan Summary:
1. Analyze current auth module structure
2. Identify security improvements
3. Refactor password hashing to use bcrypt
4. Add rate limiting to login endpoint
5. Update tests

[Approve] [Reject]

docs.title: Step 3: Review the Plan
docs.text:
View full details:

$ codegeass approval show abc123
ID: abc123
Task: refactor-auth
Status: pending
Created: 2024-01-15 09:00:00
Expires: 2024-01-15 10:00:00

Plan:
─────────────────────────────────────────────────
Phase 1: Analysis
  - Read src/auth.py and understand current structure
  - Identify security weaknesses
  - List files that import from auth module

Phase 2: Implementation
  - Replace MD5 password hashing with bcrypt
  - Add rate limiting (5 attempts per minute)
  - Add account lockout after 10 failed attempts

Phase 3: Testing
  - Update unit tests for new behavior
  - Run full test suite
  - Verify no regressions

Files to Modify:
  - src/auth.py
  - src/middleware/rate_limit.py (new)
  - tests/test_auth.py
─────────────────────────────────────────────────

docs.title: Step 4: Approve or Reject
docs.text:
If the plan looks good:

$ codegeass approval approve abc123
Plan approved. Execution continuing...

If you have concerns:

$ codegeass approval reject abc123 --reason "Rate limit should be 10 attempts, not 5"
Plan rejected. Task stopped.

docs.title: Step 5: Execution Completes
docs.text:
After approval, Claude executes the plan:

$ codegeass logs show <execution-id>
Status: completed
Duration: 5m 23s

Output:
  - Refactored src/auth.py with bcrypt
  - Created src/middleware/rate_limit.py
  - Updated 12 tests
  - All tests passing

docs.title: Telegram Interactive Approval
docs.text:
With Telegram configured, you can approve/reject directly from the chat:

🔔 Approval Required: refactor-auth

Plan Summary:
1. Refactor password hashing
2. Add rate limiting
3. Update tests

[Approve] [Reject]

Tap the button to approve or reject without using the CLI.

docs.title: Timeout Handling
docs.text:
Plans expire after a configurable timeout (default: 1 hour):

# config/settings.yaml
plan_mode:
  default_timeout: 3600  # seconds

When a plan times out: - The task is marked as failed - You receive a notification (if configured) - No changes are made

docs.title: 1. Enable Notifications
docs.text:
codegeass notification add telegram \
  --bot-token "..." \
  --chat-id "..."

Don't miss approval requests!

docs.title: 2. Review Carefully
docs.text: Read the full plan before approving. Look for: - Files that will be modified - Scope of changes - Potential risks

docs.title: 3. Set Reasonable Timeouts
docs.text:
# Long-running analysis needs longer approval window
plan_mode:
  default_timeout: 7200  # 2 hours

docs.title: 4. Use Descriptive Rejection Reasons
docs.text:
codegeass approval reject abc123 \
  --reason "Please use argon2 instead of bcrypt"

The reason helps if you re-run the task with modified prompts.

docs.title: 5. Combine with Version Control
docs.text:
Autonomous mode + plan mode + git = safe automation:

# Always verify changes after approval
git status
git diff

docs.title: Example: Complete Workflow
docs.text:
# 1. Create a plan-mode task
codegeass task create \
  --name weekly-cleanup \
  --schedule "0 6 * * 6" \
  --prompt "Clean up unused code, dead imports, and fix linting issues" \
  --mode autonomous \
  --plan-mode

# 2. Set up notifications
codegeass notification add telegram \
  --bot-token "..." \
  --chat-id "..."

# 3. Task runs Saturday at 6 AM, creates plan

# 4. You receive Telegram notification at 6:01 AM

# 5. Review when convenient
codegeass approval show <id>

# 6. Approve if looks good
codegeass approval approve <id>

# 7. Claude makes the changes

# 8. Review results
codegeass logs show <execution-id>
git status

docs.title: Plan Not Created
docs.text:
Check logs: 

codegeass logs list --status failed

Common issues: - Invalid working directory - Missing permissions - Claude CLI not found

docs.title: Approval Expired
docs.text: The plan timed out. Options: - Re-run the task: codegeass task run <task-id> - Increase timeout in settings

docs.title: Telegram Buttons Not Working
docs.text:
Ensure your bot token and chat ID are correct: 

codegeass notification test telegram

  • Execution Modes - When to use which mode

docs.title: Production Setup
docs.text: This guide covers setting up CodeGeass for 24/7 production use with automatic task scheduling.

docs.title: Quick Setup (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to set up the 24/7 scheduler is with the setup command:

codegeass setup

This automatically:

  1. Detects your operating system
  2. Installs the appropriate scheduler:
  3. macOS: launchd service
  4. Linux: systemd user timer
  5. Starts the scheduler immediately

The scheduler runs every minute and executes any due tasks.

docs.title: Verify It's Running
docs.text:
# macOS
launchctl list | grep codegeass

# Linux
systemctl --user status codegeass-scheduler.timer

docs.title: Uninstall
docs.text: codegeass uninstall-scheduler

docs.title: Manual Setup (Advanced)
docs.text: If you prefer manual configuration or need custom settings, follow the instructions below.

docs.title: Linux (systemd)
docs.text:
CodeGeass can run as a systemd user service that:

  • Starts automatically when your machine boots
  • Runs the scheduler every minute
  • Executes due tasks automatically
  • Logs all activity to the system journal

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• CodeGeass installed (pipx install codegeass)
  • A CodeGeass project initialized with tasks
  • Linux with systemd (most modern distributions)
  • User lingering enabled (for services to run without login)

docs.title: 1. Create Service Files
docs.text:
# Create systemd user directory
mkdir -p ~/.config/systemd/user

# Create service file
cat > ~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass-scheduler.service << 'EOF'
[Unit]
Description=CodeGeass Scheduler - Run due tasks
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/home/YOUR_USER/.local/bin/codegeass scheduler run-due
Environment="PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/home/YOUR_USER/.local/bin"
Environment="ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="

[Install]
WantedBy=default.target
EOF

# Create timer file
cat > ~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass-scheduler.timer << 'EOF'
[Unit]
Description=CodeGeass Scheduler Timer

[Timer]
OnBootSec=1min
OnUnitActiveSec=1min
AccuracySec=1s

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target
EOF

Replace YOUR_USER with your username, or use $HOME path.

docs.title: 2. Enable and Start
docs.text:
# Reload systemd
systemctl --user daemon-reload

# Enable lingering (allows services to run without login)
loginctl enable-linger $USER

# Enable and start the timer
systemctl --user enable codegeass-scheduler.timer
systemctl --user start codegeass-scheduler.timer

docs.title: Manual Installation
docs.text:
# Create LaunchAgents directory
mkdir -p ~/Library/LaunchAgents

# Create plist file
cat > ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist << 'EOF'
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
    <key>Label</key>
    <string>com.codegeass.scheduler</string>
    <key>ProgramArguments</key>
    <array>
        <string>/Users/YOUR_USER/.local/bin/codegeass</string>
        <string>scheduler</string>
        <string>run-due</string>
    </array>
    <key>StartInterval</key>
    <integer>60</integer>
    <key>RunAtLoad</key>
    <true/>
    <key>StandardOutPath</key>
    <string>/tmp/codegeass-scheduler.log</string>
    <key>StandardErrorPath</key>
    <string>/tmp/codegeass-scheduler.err</string>
    <key>EnvironmentVariables</key>
    <dict>
        <key>PATH</key>
        <string>/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/opt/homebrew/bin:/Users/YOUR_USER/.local/bin</string>
    </dict>
</dict>
</plist>
EOF

# Replace YOUR_USER with your username
sed -i '' "s/YOUR_USER/$USER/g" ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist

# Load the service
launchctl load ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist

docs.title: Check Status
docs.text:
# Linux - Timer status (shows next run time)
systemctl --user status codegeass-scheduler.timer

# Linux - Service status (shows last run result)
systemctl --user status codegeass-scheduler.service

# macOS
launchctl list | grep codegeass

docs.title: View Logs
docs.text:
# Linux - Follow logs in real-time
journalctl --user -u codegeass-scheduler -f

# Linux - View recent logs
journalctl --user -u codegeass-scheduler --since "1 hour ago"

# macOS
tail -f /tmp/codegeass-scheduler.log
cat /tmp/codegeass-scheduler.err

docs.title: Manual Execution
docs.text:
# Linux - Run the scheduler immediately
systemctl --user start codegeass-scheduler.service

# This is equivalent to:
codegeass scheduler run-due

docs.title: Stop and Disable
docs.text:
# Linux
systemctl --user stop codegeass-scheduler.timer
systemctl --user disable codegeass-scheduler.timer

# macOS
launchctl unload ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist

docs.title: Linux (systemd)
docs.text:
Edit ~/.config/systemd/user/codegeass-scheduler.timer:

[Timer]
# Run every minute (default)
OnUnitActiveSec=1min

# Run every 5 minutes
OnUnitActiveSec=5min

# Run every hour
OnUnitActiveSec=1h

After editing:

systemctl --user daemon-reload
systemctl --user restart codegeass-scheduler.timer

docs.title: macOS (launchd)
docs.text:
Edit ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist:

<key>StartInterval</key>
<integer>60</integer>  <!-- seconds, 60 = 1 minute -->

After editing:

launchctl unload ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist
launchctl load ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.codegeass.scheduler.plist

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
The scheduler automatically unsets ANTHROPIC_API_KEY to ensure Claude uses your subscription, not API credits.

To add custom environment variables:

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
Edit the service file and add:

[Service]
Environment="MY_VAR=value"

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
Add to the plist:

<key>EnvironmentVariables</key>
<dict>
    <key>MY_VAR</key>
    <string>value</string>
</dict>

docs.title: Service Won't Start
docs.text:
# Linux - Check for errors
journalctl --user -u codegeass-scheduler -n 50

# macOS - Check error log
cat /tmp/codegeass-scheduler.err

# Common issues:
# - codegeass not in PATH: Use full path in ExecStart/ProgramArguments
# - Working directory doesn't exist
# - Missing config: Ensure config/schedules.yaml exists

docs.title: Timer Not Running (Linux)
docs.text:
# Check timer status
systemctl --user list-timers

# Verify lingering is enabled
loginctl show-user $USER | grep Linger

# If Linger=no, enable it:
loginctl enable-linger $USER

docs.title: Service Runs But Tasks Don't Execute
docs.text:
# Check if tasks are due
codegeass scheduler upcoming

# Run manually to see output
codegeass scheduler run-due

# Check task configuration
codegeass task list

docs.title: With Notifications
docs.text:
Configure notifications to receive alerts when tasks complete or fail:

# Add Telegram notifications
codegeass notification add --provider telegram --name "My Alerts"

# Test notifications
codegeass notification test my-alerts

docs.title: With System Monitoring
docs.text:
The service logs to the system journal (Linux) or files (macOS), which can be integrated with monitoring tools:

# Linux - Export logs to a file
journalctl --user -u codegeass-scheduler --since "1 day ago" > scheduler.log

# Send alerts on errors (example with grep)
journalctl --user -u codegeass-scheduler -f | grep -i error

  • Task Creation - Create and schedule tasks

docs.title: Setting Up Notifications
docs.text: This guide walks through configuring Telegram, Discord, and Microsoft Teams notifications for CodeGeass.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Notifications alert you when: - Tasks complete successfully - Tasks fail with errors - Plan mode tasks need approval

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Bot
docs.text:
1. Open Telegram and search for @BotFather
  2. Send /newbot
  3. Choose a name (e.g., "CodeGeass Notifications")
  4. Choose a username (e.g., "myproject_codegeass_bot")
  5. Save the bot token (format: 123456:ABC-DEF...)

docs.title: Step 2: Get Your Chat ID
docs.text:
For private chats:

  1. Start a conversation with your bot
  2. Send any message
  3. Visit: https://api.telegram.org/bot<YOUR_TOKEN>/getUpdates
  4. Find "chat":{"id":123456789} in the response

For groups/channels:

  1. Add your bot to the group
  2. Send a message in the group
  3. Visit the same URL above
  4. The chat ID will be negative (e.g., -1001234567890)

docs.title: Step 3: Add to CodeGeass
docs.text:
codegeass notification add telegram \
  --bot-token "123456:ABC-DEF..." \
  --chat-id "-1001234567890"

docs.title: Step 4: Test
docs.text:
codegeass notification test telegram

You should receive a test message in Telegram.

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Webhook
docs.text:
1. Open Discord and go to your server
  2. Right-click the channel → Edit Channel
  3. Go to Integrations → Webhooks
  4. Click New Webhook
  5. Name it (e.g., "CodeGeass")
  6. Copy the Webhook URL

docs.title: Step 2: Add to CodeGeass
docs.text:
codegeass notification add discord \
  --webhook-url "https://discord.com/api/webhooks/..."

docs.title: Step 3: Test
docs.text:
codegeass notification test discord

You should see a test message in the Discord channel.

docs.title: Microsoft Teams Setup
docs.text: Teams uses Power Automate Workflows webhooks (O365 Connectors were retired in December 2025).

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Workflow Webhook
docs.text:
1. Open Microsoft Teams
  2. Click the Apps tab (left sidebar)
  3. Search for Workflows and open it
  4. Search for "Post to a channel when a webhook request is received"
  5. Click Add and follow the setup wizard (select your team and channel)
  6. Copy the HTTP POST URL (format: https://prod-XX.westus.logic.azure.com/workflows/...)

docs.title: Step 2: Add to CodeGeass
docs.text:
codegeass notification add teams \
  --webhook-url "https://prod-XX.westus.logic.azure.com/workflows/..."

docs.title: Step 3: Test
docs.text:
codegeass notification test teams

You should see a test message in the Teams channel as an Adaptive Card.

docs.title: Plan Mode Approvals with Teams
docs.text:
Teams Workflows webhooks don't support callback buttons, so CodeGeass uses Dashboard links for approval actions:

  1. When a plan mode task needs approval, Teams receives a notification with Approve, Discuss, and Cancel buttons
  2. These buttons link to the CodeGeass Dashboard (http://localhost:5173/approvals/{id})
  3. Take action in the Dashboard, and Teams will receive a status update

Dashboard URL

By default, buttons link to http://localhost:5173. Configure a custom URL when adding the channel: 

codegeass notification add teams \
  --webhook-url "YOUR_URL" \
  --config dashboard_url=https://your-dashboard.example.com

docs.title: Configuring Events
docs.text:
By default, channels receive all events. Customize in config/notifications.yaml:

channels:
  - id: telegram-main
    provider: telegram
    enabled: true
    events:
      - task_completed
      - task_failed
      - approval_required

  - id: discord-alerts
    provider: discord
    enabled: true
    events:
      - task_failed  # Only failures

docs.title: Available Events
docs.text: Event Description task_completed Task finished successfully task_failed Task failed with error approval_required Plan mode needs approval approval_timeout Approval window expired

docs.title: Multiple Channels
docs.text:
You can configure multiple channels for different purposes:

channels:
  # Personal notifications - everything
  - id: telegram-personal
    provider: telegram
    enabled: true
    events:
      - task_completed
      - task_failed
      - approval_required

  # Team channel - only failures
  - id: discord-team
    provider: discord
    enabled: true
    events:
      - task_failed

  # Ops channel - approvals only
  - id: telegram-ops
    provider: telegram
    enabled: true
    events:
      - approval_required

docs.title: Managing Channels
docs.text:
# List all channels
codegeass notification list

# Show channel details
codegeass notification show telegram-main

# Disable temporarily
codegeass notification disable telegram-main

# Re-enable
codegeass notification enable telegram-main

# Remove permanently
codegeass notification remove discord-alerts

docs.title: Credentials Security
docs.text:
Credentials are stored separately from channel config:

# Channel config (safe to commit)
cat config/notifications.yaml

# Credentials (never commit!)
cat ~/.codegeass/credentials.yaml

Set proper permissions:

chmod 600 ~/.codegeass/credentials.yaml

docs.title: Telegram Issues
docs.text:
"Chat not found" error: - Ensure the bot is added to the chat - For groups, make sure the bot has permission to send messages - Verify the chat ID is correct (negative for groups)

"Unauthorized" error: - Check the bot token is correct - Regenerate the token via @BotFather if needed

docs.title: Discord Issues
docs.text:
"Invalid webhook" error: - Verify the webhook URL is complete - Check the webhook hasn't been deleted

Messages not appearing: - Check the channel permissions - Verify the webhook is for the correct channel

docs.title: Microsoft Teams Issues
docs.text:
"Invalid webhook URL format" error: - Ensure URL starts with https:// and contains logic.azure.com/workflows or api.powerplatform.com/workflows - The old O365 Connector URLs (webhook.office.com) still work but are deprecated

Messages not appearing: - Check the Workflow is active in Power Automate - Verify the workflow hasn't been deleted or disabled - Test the webhook directly with curl: 

curl -X POST "YOUR_WEBHOOK_URL" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"type":"message","attachments":[{"contentType":"application/vnd.microsoft.card.adaptive","content":{"type":"AdaptiveCard","version":"1.4","body":[{"type":"TextBlock","text":"Test"}]}}]}'

Approval buttons don't work: - Buttons link to the Dashboard - ensure it's running at http://localhost:5173 - Configure custom dashboard URL if running elsewhere

docs.text:
# Test connection
codegeass notification test telegram

# Check configuration
codegeass notification show telegram-main

# View logs for errors
codegeass logs list --status failed

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Separate channels - Use different channels for different severity
  2. Limit events - Only subscribe to events you care about
  3. Test after setup - Always verify with test command
  4. Secure credentials - Never commit tokens/webhooks
  5. Monitor delivery - Check notifications are arriving
